Title.evidence: A dual-centre RCT of patients assigned to receive either enoxaparin or normal saline after liver transplantation was conducted.

Trial_Design.evidence: A dual-centre RCT of patients assigned to receive either enoxaparin or normal saline after liver transplantation was conducted.

Intervention.evidence: patients assigned to receive either enoxaparin or normal saline after liver transplantation

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of prophylactic anticoagulation in patients undergoing deceased-donor liver transplantation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary efficacy outcome was the incidence of venous thrombosis (portal vein thrombosis and deep vein thrombosis) and the primary safety outcome was the incidence of major bleeding.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 462 patients were recruited.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, 89 patients (19.3%) experienced venous thrombosis and 141 patients (30.5%) experienced major bleeding within 90 days after transplantation.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Subgroup analysis revealed that anticoagulation was associated with a lower risk of deep vein thrombosis in hepatocellular carcinoma patients (HR 0.44 (95% c.i. 0.23 to 0.86), P = 0.016)

Harms.evidence: The anticoagulant group demonstrated a markedly elevated incidence of major bleeding (35.5% versus 25.5%, P = 0.020).
